en_first_half: 17 September.—I was engaged after dinner in my study posting up my books, which, through press of other work and the many visits to Lucy, had fallen sadly into arrear. Suddenly the door was burst open, and in rushed my patient, with his face distorted with passion. I was thunderstruck, for such a thing as a patient getting of his own accord into the Superintendent’s study is almost unknown. Without an instant’s pause he made straight at me. He had a dinner-knife in his hand, and, as I saw he was dangerous, I tried to keep the table between us. He was too quick and too strong for me, however; for before I could get my balance he had struck at me and cut my left wrist rather severely. Before he
en_second_half: could strike again, however, I got in my right and he was sprawling on his back on the floor. My wrist bled freely, and quite a little pool trickled on to the carpet. I saw that my friend was not intent on further effort, and occupied myself binding up my wrist, keeping a wary eye on the prostrate figure all the time. When the attendants rushed in, and we turned our attention to him, his employment positively sickened me. He was lying on his belly on the floor licking up, like a dog, the blood which had fallen from my wounded wrist. He was easily secured, and, to my surprise, went with the attendants quite placidly, simply repeating over and over again: “The blood is the life! The blood is the life!”

It was then that I noticed the look of desperation in his eyes, a look that seemed to scream for help, for mercy, for someone to understand the turmoil that was raging inside him. I tried to speak, to calm him down, to reason with him, but my voice caught in my throat, and all that came out was a faint whisper. The patient's eyes never left mine, and I could see the tears welling up in them, as he continued to whisper those words, his voice growing weaker with each passing moment. I knew then that I had to act, to do something, anything, to stop this senseless tragedy from unfolding before my very eyes. As I did, he collapsed to the floor, his body shaking with sobs, his eyes still fixed on mine, as if searching for some glimmer of hope, some shred of understanding. I knelt down beside him, trying to comfort him, to reassure him that everything would be alright, that he was safe now, that he was among friends. Me explicó que el fonógrafo era una herramienta valiosa para registrar sonidos y conversaciones, y que podría ser útil para capturar evidencia de los fenómenos sobrenaturales que habíamos estado investigando. Mientras tanto, el doctor Van Helsing entró en la habitación y se sentó en una silla en el rincón, observándonos con una expresión seria. Me preguntó al doctor Seward si podía escuchar la grabación que había hecho anteriormente, y él accedió a hacerlo. Al escuchar la grabación, el doctor Van Helsing se puso de pie y comenzó a hablar en voz baja, explicando que la voz que se escuchaba en la grabación era la de un ser sobrenatural, y que era evidente que estaba tratando de comunicarse con nosotros de alguna manera. El doctor Seward se puso de pie y comenzó a discutir con el doctor Van Helsing sobre la interpretación de la grabación, mientras que yo seguía escribiendo la carta a mi amigo Arthur. La atmósfera en la habitación se volvió tensa y emocionante, y me sentí como si estuviéramos a punto de descubrir algo importante.
